Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The relative importance of generic vs. specific capacity in addressing drought vulnerability in NE Brazil

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the wake of growing vulnerability to climatic change, building the adaptive capacity of households, regions and countries has become a policy priority. Around the world, governments and international donors seek not only for new and better ways to build adaptive capacity, but also to understand how capacities are shaped by current development policy and international aid investments. Defining and developing metrics for adaptive capacity, however, is challenging on both theoretical and practical grounds. This research responds to these challenges by studying policies designed to mitigate drought impacts in Cear√°, Brazil, a state historically marked by severe and frequent droughts. Public investments fall into two main categories: those specific to reducing drought vulnerabilities and those directed towards more generic response capacities. The first category includes activities such as crop insurance and the provision of irrigation and drinking water through the development of hydrologic infrastructure. The second category includes investments in social and human development such as rural pensions, poverty reduction and education voucher programs. This research examines how the vulnerability of rainfed farm households to drought has changed through time as a function of both specific and generic government-led interventions. The research also explores how these two categories of interventions are related, both in terms of their relative importance in defining overall adaptive capacity, and in terms of how they may create synergies or be mutually conditioning.

The research uses household and key informant data collected in 1997/98 as a baseline to understand longitudinal changes in vulnerability and adaptive capacity. New primary data emerge from a survey of 500 farm households in six different geoclimatic zones in the state and from in-depth interviews with policy makers and other key informants involved in different aspects of public policy development and implementation.

This research contributes to regional development and adaptation policy by informing the debate over the relative roles and complementarities of generic and specific investments in enhancing overall adaptive capacity. The project also contributes to building theory on the mechanisms through which change in livelihood practices and entitlements over time can result in vulnerability reduction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Agricultural households worldwide are increasingly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change. In Northeast Brazil the suffering and hardship that poor subsistence farmers face under severe droughts is well documented.  Public officials must not only implement policies that provide drought relief, but also that build the adaptive capacity of these farmers--that is, their ability to prepare, respond and recover from future climate events. Accomplishing this is particularly difficult in impoverished rural areas. While many scholars agree that the poor will suffer disproportionately the impacts of climate impact (see for example Chapter 15 of the IPCC WGII report released in 2014), it is still unclear what kinds of resources are helpful for building adaptive capacity among poor communities, and how development-related interventions (e.g. anti-poverty programs) can contribute to this process. Furthermore, defining and developing metrics for adaptive capacity is challenging on both theoretical and practical grounds.

In this project, we sought to improve understanding of the linkages between development investments, drought risk management and poverty. First created a theoretical model that characterized capacities in two main types: generic capacities, addressing deficiencies in basic human development needs (e.g., health, income, education, security) and specific capacities that address resource needed to anticipate and respond to specific (climatic) threats (e.g. access to irrigation and crop insurance).  We explored both how these two sets of capacity relate to each other and their relative importance in terms of reducing household vulnerability. Figure 1 depicts our theoretical framework.

Second, we sought to assess the adaptive capacity of smallholder households through time by comparing representative household survey data collected in 2012 with baseline data we had collected in 1998. Household data included demographic and economic information, agricultural management, risk management strategies, and food security and other drought impacts. One advantage of our study in terms of design is that between 1998 and 2012 the Brazilian government invested heavily in a broad anti-poverty program, called Bolsa Família. The program transfers cash to poor households provided they keep their minor children in school and vaccinate them when they are infants. Additionally, both years of data collection corresponded with severe droughts. This ‘natural’ experiment permitted a comparison of vulnerability through time and an assessment of the role of development interventions in increasing adaptive capacity in ways that are not possible in studies that focus on only one drought event. Using statistical models and Multicriteria Decision Analysis, we were able to evaluate the significance of different forms of capacity in differential drought impacts and responses in the two periods.

Our results show that although the 2012 drought was less severe in terms of rainfall than the 1998 drought, its impacts were not. In 1998, 22% of our households reported food insecurity due the drought, and in 2012 this percentage increased to 35% of all the households, despite the cash-transfer program. Our results suggest that while indicators of human development increased and poverty fell significantly in the period of analysis, there were minimal investments in specific capacities that could help to manage drought risk. Hence while Bolsa Família has indeed reduced poverty, it has not been sufficient to increase the capacity of households to manage the risk of food insecurity. This indicates a ‘poverty trap’ in which families are constantly coping with drought but failing to overcome the conditions that make them vulnerable.
